Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the step-parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: The carpenter should be on time in the work area
Story: I woke up before dawn, the house still and quiet except for the soft breathing of my stepdaughter in the next room. The weight of the home loan pressed on my chest—I had two months to make sure we didn’t fall behind. Every dollar counted, and I needed every hour at the carpentry site to keep us afloat. But as I rushed to get ready, my phone buzzed: my boss’s reminder about the new safety protocols. “No shortcuts, no late arrivals,” he’d said. I knew the risks—one slip, one missed check, and someone could get hurt. But if I left now, I’d barely see my stepdaughter before she woke up, and I’d have to skip breakfast to make it on time. If I was late, I could lose hours, maybe even the job. If I rushed, I might miss a safety step. My mind spun with the demands—be a responsible parent, keep the house, keep the job, keep everyone safe. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, heart pounding, torn between the door and the kitchen, between my family and my work.
